maml:description.maml:para: Get WMI filters from Active Directory.
Get WMI filters from Active Directory and parse them into objects.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Name of the WMI filter to return.
The domain to search for WMI filters.
Credential for binding to the domain.
The GUID of the WMI filter to return.
The domain to search for WMI filters.
Credential for binding to the domain.
The Name of the WMI filter to return.
The GUID of the WMI filter to return.
The domain to search for WMI filters.
Credential for binding to the domain.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Will return a list of all WMI filters in the current user's domain.
Will return a list of all WMI filters with 'Server' in the name from the domain contoso.com using the CONTOSO Administrator account.
Will return the WMI filter with the GUID '6a3a8a8d-2072-4596-8b5b-b24bcf0486ce' from the current user's domain.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new WMI filter in Active Directory.
Create a new WMI filter object in Active Directory.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Name of the WMI filter to create. Must be unique.
An optional description of what the WMI filter does.
Allows you to optionally specify the GUID of the WMI filter. This is useful for restoring WMI filters from backup. Defaults to a random GUID.
Either string filter(s) or WMI filter object(s) returned by New-WmiFilterObject.
The destination domain.
Credential for binding to the domain.
The Name of the WMI filter to create. Must be unique.
An optional description of what the WMI filter does.
Allows you to optionally specify the GUID of the WMI filter. This is useful for restoring WMI filters from backup. Defaults to a random GUID.
Either string filter(s) or WMI filter object(s) returned by New-WmiFilterObject.
The destination domain.
Credential for binding to the domain.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-GPWmiFilter -Name 'Servers Only' -Description 'Selects computers where the product type is Domain Controller (2) or Server (3)' -Filter 'SELECT * FROM Win32_OperatingSystem WHERE ProductType = 2 OR ProductType = 3'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example would create a filter that selects computers where the product type is Domain Controller (2) or Server (3).

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new WmiFilterList for use in WMI filters.
Create a new WmiFilterList for use in WMI filters.

maml:Description.maml:para: WMI filter objects from New-WmiFilterObject.
The WMI filter. The pattern 'SELECT <something> FROM <somewhere> WHERE <sometest>' is enforced.
The namespace to use when executing the query. Defaults to 'root\CIMv2'.
The query language to use. Current versions of Windows only support WQL, which is the default.
WMI filter objects from New-WmiFilterObject.
The WMI filter. The pattern 'SELECT <something> FROM <somewhere> WHERE <sometest>' is enforced.
The namespace to use when executing the query. Defaults to 'root\CIMv2'.
The query language to use. Current versions of Windows only support WQL, which is the default.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-WmiFilterList 'SELECT * FROM Win32_OperatingSystem WHERE ProductType = 2 OR ProductType = 3'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example would create a filter that selects computers where the product type is Domain Controller (2) or Server (3).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $WmiFilter1 = New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_OperatingSystem WHERE ProductType = 3' $WmiFilter2 = New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_TerminalServiceSetting WHERE TerminalServerMode = 1' -NameSpace 'root\CIMv2\TerminalServices' New-WmiFilterList $WmiFilter1, $WmiFilter2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example would create a filter list that selects member servers which have terminal server enabled. Note we are not using the default namespace for one of the filters.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $WmiFilterList = New-WmiFilterList New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_OperatingSystem WHERE ProductType = 3' -WmiFilterList $WmiFilterList New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_TerminalServiceSetting WHERE TerminalServerMode = 1' -NameSpace 'root\CIMv2\TerminalServices' -WmiFilterList $WmiFilterList

dev:remarks.maml:para: This is the same result as Example 2, however this time we are appending filters to a WmiFilterList object instead.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new WmiFilterObject for use in WMI filters.
Create a new WmiFilterList for use in WMI filters.

maml:Description.maml:para: The WMI filter. The pattern 'SELECT <something> FROM <somewhere> WHERE <sometest>' is enforced.
The namespace to use when executing the query. Defaults to 'root\CIMv2'.
The query language to use. Current versions of Windows only support WQL, which is the default.
WMI filter list to append filters to.
The WMI filter. The pattern 'SELECT <something> FROM <somewhere> WHERE <sometest>' is enforced.
The namespace to use when executing the query. Defaults to 'root\CIMv2'.
The query language to use. Current versions of Windows only support WQL, which is the default.
WMI filter list to append filters to.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_OperatingSystem WHERE ProductType = 2 OR ProductType = 3'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example would create a filter that selects computers where the product type is Domain Controller (2) or Server (3). This object would have to be added to a WmiFilterList before use.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $WmiFilterList = New-WmiFilterList New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_OperatingSystem WHERE ProductType = 3' -WmiFilterList $WmiFilterList New-WmiFilterObject 'SELECT * FROM Win32_TerminalServiceSetting WHERE TerminalServerMode = 1' -NameSpace 'root\CIMv2\TerminalServices' -WmiFilterList $WmiFilterList

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example would create a filter list that selects member servers which have terminal server enabled. Note we are not using the default namespace for one of the filters.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove WMI filters from Active Directory.
Remove WMI filters from Active Directory after validating that they are not in use by any Group Policy objects.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Name of the WMI filter.
The domain to search for WMI filters.
Credential for binding to the domain.

Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
The GUID of the WMI filter.

Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Credential for binding to the domain.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Will remove the WMI filter with the GUID '6a3a8a8d-2072-4596-8b5b-b24bcf0486ce' from the current user's domain.

maml:description.maml:para: Set registry values on domain controller to allow writing to system only attributes.
Set registry values on domain controller to allow writing to system only attributes.

Disable writing to System Only objects in AD.
Credential for authenticating to a remote computer.
The remote computer to connect to.
Enable writing to System Only objects in AD.

Enable writing to System Only objects in AD.
Disable writing to System Only objects in AD.
The remote computer to connect to.
Enable writing to System Only objects in AD.
Disable writing to System Only objects in AD.
Credential for authenticating to a remote computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Enables System Only Change on dc.contoso.com.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Set-GPWmiFilter -Name 'Servers Only' -Description 'Selects computers where the product type is Domain Controller (2) or Server (3)'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example would update the description of the WMI filter with the name 'Servers Only'.

maml:description.maml:para: Check if 'Allow System Only Change' is enabled. attributes.
Check if 'Allow System Only Change' is enabled. attributes.

Credential for authenticating to a remote computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns TRUE if System Only Change is enabled, or FALSE if it is disabled.
